Award.AwardTitle: The 2016 Paul J. Sally, Jr. Midwest Representation Theory Conference
Award.AbstractNarration:
The 2016 Paul J. Sally, Jr. Midwest Representation Theory Conference will be held October 14-16, 2016, on the campus of University of Iowa, Iowa City, Iowa. The conference will gather established experts, junior researchers and graduate students for the purpose of discussing and disseminating new research results. Representation theory is a branch of mathematics devoted to the study of symmetries of mathematical and physical systems that has applications to many other areas of mathematics, particularly number theory and geometry. This is the 42nd anniversary of the original Midwest Conference. Over the years it has served as an important source of information for experts in the field and numerous collaborative efforts have originated from these meetings. This year's meeting will continue that tradition.

The conference will feature ten main talks, including talks by young researchers, on a broad range of topics in representation theory of groups over non-archimedean local fields. Topics covered may include Plancherel formula, supercuspidal representations, the structure of smooth representations of reductive groups via types and covers, functorial transfer to general linear groups, and the Local Langlands Correspondence. The conference website is: http://www.math.uiowa.edu/MRTC_2016/.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The 2016 Paul J. Sally, Jr. Midwest Representation Theory Conference was held at University of Iowa during October 14-16, 2016. This 42nd edition of the annual Midwest Representation Conference, re-named since 2015 after its founder Paul J. Sally, Jr., also honored Phil Kutzko on his seventieth birthday. There were 10 speakers: Shuyang Cheng (Chicago), Kwangho Choiy (SIU), Tasho Kaletha (Michigan), Camelia Karimianpour (Michigan), Ju-Lee Kim (MIT), Yeansu Kim (JNU, South Korea), Fiona Murnaghan (Toronto), Alan Roche (University of Oklahaoma), Shaun Stevens (UEA) and Dani Szpruch (Howard). Their lectures covered a wide range of topics in the representation theory of p-adic groups including applications to number theory and harmonic analysis. Keeping with the tradition, many of these speakers are early career researchers including two graduate students on their way to starting a new postdoctoral position. Additional information  (including some lecture notes) about the conference may be found at http://homepage.divms.uiowa.edu/~mkrishna/2016MRTC-WEB/index.html. For the conference, a total of 45 participants were supported including the speakers. There were several local unsupported participants (including one organizer). Of the supported participants, 12 were graduate students, 15 were junior researchers (defined as those with completed Ph. D., but yet to gain tenure) and 18 were senior researchers. There were 8 supported female participants. Seven of the 45 supported participants were from foreign institutions (Canada and the U.K.). University of Iowa generously supplemented the funds provided by this award. The diverse population had plenty of opportunities for research collaboration as well as time for informal discussions about current and future research. This mixture of junior, mid-carrier and senior researchers is one of the hallmarks of the Midwest Representation Theory conference providing a robust environment for nurturing and advancing research in the field.
